result.execSummary:
The defendant Mark A. Hancock was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Defendant shall provide a DNA sample. 
Defendant shall have such assessments, treatment, counseling and programming as DOC deems appropriate. 
Defendant shall not possess or consume any controlled substances unless prescribed and to be taken only as prescribed.
Defendant shall submit to random observed testing for controlled substance upon request of DOC, law enforcement, or designee.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Mark A. Hancock

records.addlTxt: Defendant Mark A. Hancock in court.  Attorney Lisa A. Riniker in court for State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Lui Moefu in court for Mark A. Hancock. Per agreement, defendant will be pleading to charge. State will recommend 2 years probation with the following conditions: counseling deemed appropriate by DOC, take meds as prescribed, pay restitution, court costs, and submit to random drug testing. Court reviews plea questionnaire and finds defendant freely and knowingly waives rights. Defendant pleads no contest. Court accepts plea and finds defendant guilty. State heard. Attorney Moefu heard. Court heard and orders 2 years probation with the following conditions: to have such assessment, treatment, programming, and counseling that DOC deems appropriate, not to possess or consume any controlled substance unless prescribed and to be taken only as prescribed, submit to random observed testing upon requests of DOC, law enforcement, or court designee, and court costs are waived. If revoked,  3 days credit.
